text.p: These are the leading stories in the Zimbabwe press on Friday. Reuters has not verified these stories and does not vouch for their accuracy.

- Zimbabwe's home affairs minister Dumiso Dabengwa early this week temporarily banned all public demonstrations in the interest of law and order, a move strongly contested by lawyers and human rights activists.

- Over Z$2.3 billion worth of property purchased in South Africa for war-related purposes by Zimbabwe's colonial governments can no longer be accounted for, the Zimbabwe Independent learnt earlier this week.

- Some Zimbabwean medical workers, part of a group currently on a strike to press for better salaries and working conditions which has paralysed the country's health system, have gone back to work on compassionate grounds to help attend to desperate cases.

- Regional investment group Trans Zambezi Industries whose diversified portfolio has been built through acquisitions, is understood to have bought a substantial shareholding in Zimbabwean discount company DCZ which made its stockmarket debut a few months ago.

- The Zimbabwean government has appointed a six-member sub-committee of the cabinet to solve the health crisis brought about by a strike by junior health workers now nearing its fourth week, while the Zimbabwe Congress of Trade Unions has started mediating between government and workers.

- Zimbabwe's Supreme court on Thursday reserved judgement on an application by TS Masiyiwa chairman Strive Masiyiwa for an order to force the government to issue his company's subsidiary Econet with a cellular telephone licence.
